discourse_list.title: "Code is Law" vs "Bankruptcy Law is Law"

content.content: The “Code is Law” meme is up against a formidable foe – The “Bankruptcy Law is Law” counter-meme. The “Bankruptcy Law is Law” counter-meme has some strengths. The “Code is Law” meme has an inherent weakness. As its inherent weakness, the “Code is Law” meme confidently mistakes code for law. Code is contracts, code is enforcement, but law is law. The U.S. Bankruptcy Code is exceptionally powerful and provides debtors and the bankruptcy court with tools to challenge the “Code is Law” meme. This post identifies one of those tools - the automatic stay. This posting only relates to the United States and no other jurisdiction and introduces some basic concepts. I will develop the analysis of this post in subsequent posts.  Automatic Stay The smart contract “Code is Law” meme is likely to find itself lined up for battle against the “Bankruptcy Law is Law” counter-meme. Specifically, the battle will likely arise between the automatic liquidation mechanism in smart contracts and the U.S. Bankruptcy Code’s “automatic stay” provision. Section 362(a)(3) of the Bankruptcy Code provides that the mere filing of a bankruptcy petition prohibits “any act to obtain possession of property of the estate or of the property from the estate or to exercise control over property of the estate.” Section 362(k)(1) provides a mechanism for the debtor to recover damages against any creditor that violates the automatic stay. Damages may include actual and punitive damages. For those not versed in bankruptcy terminology, “estate” is the debtor. Timing is Key Like most things in life, timing is everything. The automatic stay only applies to acts taken after the Chapter 11 filing. Chapter 11 is the process in which a debtor rehabilitates its business to emerge as a going concern. It does not automatically result in termination of the business.  1192×318 73.7 KB  Liquidation of Collateral A smart contract’s liquidation of collateral pre-petition will not violate the automatic stay provisions. But, a smart contract’s liquidation of collateral post-petition will likely violate the automatic stay provisions. Next In my next posting, I will explore whether a smart contract’s liquidation of collateral constitutes an act for purposes of the Bankruptcy Code. After, I will examine whether a smart contract’s liquidation of collateral constitutes a “wilful act” and thus support a claim for punitive damages. Finally, I will touch on how this all might apply to a DAO.

There are multiple carve-outs to the automatic stay. In the case above, the most applicable carve-out may be Sec. 362(b)(6). This section provides: “under subsection (a) of this section, of the exercise by a commodity broker, forward contract merchant, stockbroker, financial institution, financial participant, or securities clearing agency of any contractual right (as defined in section 555 or 556) under any security agreement or arrangement or other credit enhancement forming a part of or related to any commodity contract, forward contract or securities contract, or of any contractual right (as defined in section 555 or 556) to offset or net out any termination value, payment amount, or other transfer obligation arising under or in connection with 1 or more such contracts, including any master agreement for such contracts;” More food for thought on top of the points raised by @PaperImperium.

Thank you! That feels very close to what DeFi protocols do, although we may not meet the definitional requirements to be one of those entities. It does give us a specific point to lobby governments on at least.

The carve-outs @christiancdpetersen referenced above result from decades of industry trade association efforts with regulatory authorities and international policy institutions coordinating globally to push through laws at the country/nation level. A core, essential, foundational part of the strategy was the commissioning of netting legal opinions from local counsel all around the world. In the case of the section quoted above, a significant portion of the work was paid for and stewarded by the International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA). My first year as an associate at Cravath, Swaine & Moore in 1998-99, I worked as North American Outside Counsel for ISDA and was responsible for organizing netting opinions for over a dozen jurisdictions that formed the analytical basis upon which policy makers could rely for exclusions from the certain bankruptcy risk the industry relies on today. Submitted by @christiancdpetersen and @amskar Does a smart contract’s liquidation of collateral constitute an act for purposes of Bankruptcy Code? As established in the previous post, a smart contract’s liquidation of collateral pre-petition does not violate the automatic stay. However, a smart contract’s automatic liquidation of collateral post-petition may violate the automatic stay. Section § 362(a)(3) of the US Bankruptcy Code prohibits “any act to obtain possession of property of the estate … or to exercise control over property” during the automatic stay. For a smart contract to violate the automatic stay, it must be considered an act that allows the creditor to take control or possession of the property. If a smart contract’s immediate liquidation of collateral is an act, then the liquidation may violate the automatic stay. So what are the arguments?  No. Smart contracts are automatic and do not constitute “acts”. Smart contracts execute automatically without human enforcement. A smart contract’s liquidation of collateral is not an act because the contract executes independent of any creditor action post-petition. Although the control of the property changes, the creditor is not actively taking steps to obtain control over the debtor’s property. A creditor is not responsible if a smart contract liquidates collateral, because the creditor has not “acted”.  Yes. Possession and/or control of the property has changed. If a smart contract liquidates collateral post-petition, the creditor has assumed control and receives the benefits of the property. In the event of a Chapter 11 filing, the creditor must ensure that it does not assume control of the estate’s property.  Yes. Technology is authorized by humans. The computers that execute smart contracts are agents of the humans who authorize them. The creditor is responsible for the smart contract because it is responsible for the technology that executes it. The act of liquidation is actually planned. In the U.S., the Uniform Electronic Transactions Act defines an “electronic agent” as a computer program that can initiate an action without review or action by an individual.  Yes. The creation of a smart contract is an act itself. It is an act to create, authorize, and consent to a smart contract that may eventually violate the automatic stay. The creation of the smart contract itself might constitute an act under the Bankruptcy Code.  The Bankruptcy Code has not yet dealt with the implications of second-generation Blockchain-based smart contracts. And from the above, there can be arguments on both sides of a particular issue – what is an “act”?  Introduction – @amskar is university student who expressed interest in both law and DeFi. She is interning with me over the summer and I am giving her exposure to some of the pending transactions and having her research various legal/DeFi topics.

FT article: tether recovery of celsius loan An interesting read - a few quotes herefrom you might find interesting:  Can Celsius recover . . . loan liquidations completed in the 90 days before filing?” Celsius’s law firm Kirkland & Ellis said in a presentation to the New York bankruptcy court last week. The question was among the “legal issues critical to the outcome of the case”   “We’re in an area where the law is quite uncertain and quite at odds with the market’s general expectations,” said Brandon Hammer, a bankruptcy lawyer at Cleary Gottlieb. Many in crypto markets have wrongly assumed that simply taking possession of crypto pledged as collateral will protect their position as a secured lender under bankruptcy law, Hammer said. In fact, they could still be forced to return the assets, leaving them only with an unsecured claim equal to the value of the loan.   “One of the things that’s going to be examined is whether or not Tether was fully secured. Did Tether properly perfect its security in its collateral?” said Tad Davidson, co-head of the bankruptcy practice at Hunton Andrews Kurth.   “The way you perfect security over bitcoin hasn’t been tested in any kind of litigation,” said Jonathan Cho, a bankruptcy lawyer at Allen & Overy. The uncertainty was heightened when El Salvador declared bitcoin legal tender last year. The Uniform Commercial Code, rules followed by almost all US states, labels mediums of exchange recognised by foreign governments as physical money over which security can only be perfected by physical possession — a problem for digital currency.   The UCC was updated this month to include specific rules on crypto security that focuses on control of the asset. But the rules are not yet law and are not retrospective. Current best practice in crypto markets has involved issuing public documents known as UCC filings that declare a security interest in intangible assets, or applying rules on investment assets that involve a third-party custodian taking control of the asset, lawyers said.

@christiancdpetersen , thanks for this, and I hope you don’t mind me jumping in on a slightly stale post. My rough understanding of the liquidation process is that it further relies on “keepers” that execute the code to effect the liquidation, i.e., seeing that capital is at risk, “biting” it to start the auction process, bidding the price, and finally taking the property in exchange for DAI.  See https://docs.makerdao.com/miscellaneous/liquidations-1.2-system-deprecated/flipper-detailed-documentation.  While a keeper may certainly automate parts of this process, my understanding is that they would typically operate a node and monitor and make bidding decision off-chain, since on chain processing would be prohibitively expensive in terms of gas. Under this flow, it seems much more clear that the Keepers have both the mens rea and actus reus to be in violation of the automatic stay, and I would think that the trustees would try mightily to get jx over them to claw back any liquidated assets.  @jameskmccall is absolutely correct that this could lead to some bad game theory implications for bystanders in the DAO when it comes to liquidators that believe themselves to be outside the jurisdictional reach of the bankruptcy court.
